abstract.text: The first residue of the model, S835, was set to position "d" of the first heptad repeat and the modelled periodicity was 7-7-7-7-7-7. The side chains were placed by using SCWRL 3.0 (Canutescu et al., 2003) and manually adjusted in Swiss-PdbViewer (Guex and Peitsch, 1997). Missing intermolecular and intramolecular salt bridges, namely R845-E850, K866-E871 and E868-R872 respectively, were introduced and torsion angles of the core side chains were adjusted to the usual values in coiled-coil structures. Finally, the model was optimized by performing 100 rounds of steepest-descent energy minimization as implemented in Swiss-PdbViewer and coiled-coil parameters were validated using TWISTER (Strelkov and Burkhard, 2002) .

Yeast two-hybrid screening. Bait and prey constructs were co-transformed into yeast cells and positive co-transformants (containing both bait and prey plasmids) picked from selective medium SD/-LT (lacking tryptophan and leucine). These were restreaked onto selective media SD/-LTH (lacking tryptophan, leucine and histidine), SD/-LTH with 2 mM 3-Amino-1, 2, 4-triazole (3-AT) and SD/-LTAH (lacking tryptophan, leucine, histidine and adenine) respectively to activate the reporter genes HIS3 and ADE2. PC2 C-terminus (CT2, 680-968) and PC1 C-terminus (CT1, 4107-4303) or their truncations were subcloned into the bait (BD) vector pGBKT7 or prey (AD) vector pGADT7 (Clontech). Site-specific mutations of CT2 or CT1 were generated as described previously (Streets et al., 2006) . The constructs pGBKT7-53 (p53) and pGBADT7-T (SV40 T-antigen) were used as a pair of positive controls.

hPKD1 was subcloned in pcDNA3.1(+). Four clones were generated: clone 1 was untagged, clone 2 had N-terminal FLAG and C-terminal HA tags, clone 3 had a C-terminal FLAG and clone 4 had a C-terminal myc tag. The PC1-R4227X truncation mutant was similarly generated except that it had an HA epitope tag. hPKD2 C-terminus was subcloned in pcDNA3.1(+) and N-terminally fused to CD8α. Site specific mutations were introduced into PKD1 and PKD2 using the Quick-change site-directed mutagenesis protocol (Stratagene) as previously described and verified by nucleotide sequencing. All mutant cDNAs were subcloned into pcDNA3.1(+) expression vectors, except hPKD2-S812A and hPKD2L1, which were subcloned into cdmo and pQIEGFP vectors (Invitrogen), respectively.

HEK 293T, COS-7, CHO and MDCK cell lines were maintained in Dulbecco's modified eagle medium (DMEM-HEPES: GlutaMAXTM-l, 4,500 mg.l-1 glucose, 25 mM HEPES buffer) supplemented with 10% decomplemented fetal bovine serum, 1 % MEM non-essential amino acids and 1 % sodium pyruvate. Cells at 60% confluence were transfected by Jet PEI (Polyplus transfection) or Lipofectamine 2000 (Invitrogen) in 0.7 cm² wells coated with poly-L-lysine (5 µg.ml-1) or in 100 mm dishes. Neurons were isolated from Sprague Dawley rat superior cervical ganglia (SCGs). Animals were used in accordance with the European Community directive on the care and use of animals (86/609/CEE). SCG neurons were cultured on glass coverslips coated with laminin. Endotoxin-free plasmids (PureLink HiPure Plasmid Maxiprep Kit, Invitrogen) were diluted to 100 ng/µl in a KCl-based Ca2+-free internal solution (pH 7.3) containing 0.2 % FITC-dextran (70 kDa) and were pressure-injected 3 into the nucleus of SCG cells. Cells were maintained in culture for a further 2 days prior to patch clamp recording or calcium imaging.

GST and MBP pull-down assays. 1-2 µg of the GST fusion protein and the potential partner protein (1-2 µg) were incubated in 300 µl binding buffer (1×TBST with 0.2 % Tween20) for 1 hr at RT with gentle rotation. 40 µl of 50 % Glutathione Sepharose 4B beads was then added and the mixture incubated with rotating for an additional hour. The beads were sedimented by centrifugation at 6000 rpm for 2 min, and washed up to 6 times with 1 ml of ice-cold PBS (pH 7.3). Bound proteins were eluted either using 25 µl of elution buffer or by boiling for 5-10 4 min in reducing sample buffer. In the MBP pull-down assay, a similar protocol was followed except that amylose resin was used instead of glutathione beads.

Cross-linking assay. The cross-linker disuccinimidyl suberate (DSS) was prepared firstly in 100 % DMSO at 20 mM and diluted just before use. 5 µl of cross-linker reagent was added to the protein samples (0.5-1 µg) to a total volume of 50 µl. The reaction mixture was incubated at RT for 30 min or on ice for 2 hr. Following the incubation, 2.5 µl of stop solution (1 M Tris-HCl, pH 7.6) was added at a final concentration of 50 mM and incubated for 15 min. 10 µl of the reaction mixture was transferred in a new tube and mixed with 2× loading buffer, then analyzed by SDS-PAGE and western blotting.

For sedimentation velocity, 0.42 ml samples were centrifuged in 1.2 cm path length 2-sector epon meniscus-matching centrepiece cells (sample in RH sector, reference buffer in LH sector) with sapphire windows in an 8-place An-50 Ti analytical rotor running in an Optima XL-I analytical ultracentrifuge (Beckman Instruments) at 50,000 rpm and at 20 C. Changes in 5 solute concentration were detected by Rayleigh interference and radial 287 nm absorbance scans. 122 scans of each cell were collected during 9 hr. Results were analyzed by wholeboundary profile analysis using the program Sedfit v 9.4 (Schuck, 2000) . Also g(s) analysis was performed using the program DCDT+ (Philo, 2000) .

For sedimentation equilibrium, 0.1 ml samples were centrifuged in 1.2 cm path length 6sector epon centrepiece cells with sapphire windows in an 8-place An-50 Ti analytical rotor running in an Optima XL-I analytical ultracentrifuge at a temperature of 5 C. The samples were spun at 3,000 rpm for 18 hr, then 13,000 rpm for 75 hr, and 18,000 rpm for 46 hr.

Radial absorbance scans (10 replicates, radial step size 0.001 cm) were performed at intervals of 4 hr. Interference scans were also collected. Scans were judged to be at equilibrium by plotting radial offset vs time using the program WinMatch (www.biotech.uconn.edu/auf/).
The results were analyzed using the program Sedanal v 4.78 (Stafford and Sherwood, 2004) .

Proposed organization of polycystin ion channel complex in the plasma membrane and

Top panel: PC1 and PC2 co-assemble via their COOH termini to form a plasmalemmal polycystin complex. The C-terminal dimerization of PC2 mediated by CC2 domains is essential for binding to PC1 and reconstitution of a functional polycystin complex. However, the actual PC1 binding domain is distal to CC2. The existence of an N-terminal dimerization domain facilitates the assembly of the four PC2 monomers into a homotetramer (Feng et al., 2008) . These polycystin complexes may mediate Ca 2+ influx in response to mechanochemical stimulation of the primary cilium.
